title: Interactive Apps
text:
Explore key industrial organisation models with these interactive Shiny applications. Each app allows you to adjust parameters and observe how equilibrium outcomes change.






NoteRunning the Apps



These apps require R and Shiny. You can run them locally by opening the .R file in RStudio or Positron and clicking “Run App”.





File: cournot-duopoly/cournot-duopoly-app.R
Visualise the best response functions (reaction curves) in a Cournot duopoly with homogeneous goods.
Key concepts:

Best response functions: \(R_i(q_j)\) and \(R_j(q_i)\)
Cournot-Nash equilibrium as the intersection of reaction curves
Effect of cost asymmetries on equilibrium quantities
Iso-profit contours

Parameters you can adjust:

Demand intercept (\(a\)) and slope (\(b\))
Marginal costs for each firm (\(c_i\), \(c_j\))
Iso-profit curve levels





File: monopolist-profits/monopolist-best-response-app.R
Explore the residual demand problem facing a Cournot firm, showing how a firm’s optimal output depends on rival production.
Key concepts:

Residual demand function
Profit maximisation given rival output
Derivation of the best response function
Shift in profit curves as rival output changes

Parameters you can adjust:

Demand intercept (\(a\)) and slope (\(b\))
Marginal cost (\(c\))
Rival output level (\(q_j\))





File: profit-possibility-cournot/profit-possibility-frontier-app.R
Visualise the profit possibility frontier showing all Pareto-efficient profit combinations for two Cournot firms.
Key concepts:

Cournot equilibrium profits (\(\pi_i^C\), \(\pi_j^C\))
Monopoly profits (\(\pi_i^M\), \(\pi_j^M\))
Collusion profits and the contract curve
Stackelberg leader/follower profits
Inefficiency of non-cooperative equilibrium

Parameters you can adjust:

Demand intercept (\(a\)) and slope (\(b\))
Marginal costs for each firm (\(c_i\), \(c_j\))
Minimum profit constraints





File: salop-circle/salop-circular-city-app.R
Visualise the Salop circular city model of spatial/horizontal product differentiation with 3 firms.
Key concepts:

Spatial competition on a circular market
Transportation costs and consumer choice
Market boundaries between firms
Effect of pricing on market shares
Horizontal product differentiation

Parameters you can adjust:

Consumer location on the circle
Each firm’s price towards neighbouring firms
Market boundary positions

title: Interactive Apps
text:
Getting Started
To run any app:

Ensure you have R installed with the shiny and ggplot2 packages
Open the .R file in RStudio or Positron
Click the “Run App” button or run shiny::runApp("path/to/app.R")

# Install required packages if needed
install.packages(c("shiny", "ggplot2"))

Interactive apps based on original Mathematica demonstrations by Flavio Toxvaerd (University of Cambridge), reimplemented in R Shiny.

title: EC5230 Industrial Organisation
text:
This is the course website for EC5230 Industrial Organisation at the University of St Andrews.
Industrial Organisation studies the structure of firms and markets, strategic interactions between firms, and the effects of market power on economic outcomes. This course covers both theoretical foundations and practical applications, examining how firms behave in imperfectly competitive markets.

title: EC5230 Industrial Organisation
text:
Course Overview
Module Credits: 15 (Semester 2, Optional)

Topics Covered
This module explores key concepts in industrial economics across twelve weeks:

Competition and Oligopoly Coordination (Week 1)
Product Differentiation (Week 2)
Economics of Innovation (Week 3)
Economics of Patents and IPRs (Week 4)
Multi-stage Games (Week 5)
Cooperative R&D (Week 7)
Bundling (Week 8)
Advertising (Week 9)
Mergers (Week 11)
Sustainable Industrialisation (Week 12)



Intended Learning Outcomes
By the end of the module, you will be able to:

Understand how Industrial Organisation deepens the analysis of firm behaviour in imperfectly competitive markets
Select and apply appropriate models to analyse various issues in industrial economics
Develop skills in analysing economic behaviour through game theory
Identify and critically evaluate relevant research papers and real-world examples



Sustainability in the Curriculum
This module contributes to UN Sustainable Development Goals:

Goal 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure - Examining how patents and IPRs impact innovation disclosure and cooperative R&D
Goal 12: Responsible Consumption and Production - Analysing network effects in technology adoption and sustainable industrialisation

title: EC5230 Industrial Organisation
text:
Course Materials






NoteNavigation



Use the navigation bar above to access different sections of the course.



Lectures
Lecture slides covering key topics in industrial organisation, including market structure, firm behaviour, oligopoly theory (Cournot, Bertrand, Stackelberg), product differentiation, innovation, and mergers.


Exercises
Problem sets with and without solutions to help you practice the concepts covered in lectures. Tutorials focus on live problem-solving (numerical and discussion/interpretation questions).


Interactive Apps
Interactive visualisations to explore key economic models:

Cournot duopoly best responses
Monopolist profit maximisation
Profit possibility frontiers
Salop circular city model

title: EC5230 Industrial Organisation
text:
Textbooks and Readings
There is no single prescribed textbook. The course draws on chapters from:

Belleflamme, P. & Peitz, M. (2015). Industrial Organisation: Markets and Strategies (2nd ed.)
Shy, O. (1996). Industrial Organisation: Theory and Applications
Scotchmer, S. (2004). Innovation and Incentives
Church, J. & Ware, R. (2000). Industrial Organization: A Strategic Approach

Journal articles are available through the online reading list and cited at the end of each lecture.

Class Test: 50-minute in-person test covering Weeks 1–5, including a problem-solving question and a discussion-based question (Week 6, during lecture slot)
Policy Recommendation: Written report (max 1,000 words) analysing a real-world industrial organisation issue of your choice, submitted via MMS by 15 April 2026, 17:00
Final Examination: Three-hour in-person exam covering all module content (Weeks 1–5, 7–9, 11–12)

title: EC5230 Industrial Organisation
text:
Prerequisites

Good understanding of intermediate microeconomics (market structures, competition, welfare analysis, game theory)
Basic algebra and calculus (optimisation)
No econometric or statistical knowledge required

title: EC5230 Industrial Organisation
text:
Course Structure

Lectures: 10 × 2 hours (Weeks 1–5, 7–9, 11–12; no lecture during Spring Break)
Tutorials: 5 × 1 hour (Weeks 3, 5, 7, 9, 12)
Independent Learning Week: Week 10
